description.narrative: Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The Swedish Program for ICT in Developing Regions (SPIDER) work with ICT for democracy, health and education.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 The Swedish Program for Information and Communication Technology in Developing Regions (Spider) är ett fristående center inom Institutionen för data- och systemvetenskap (DSV) vid Stockholms universitet. Sedan 2004 arbetar Spider aktivt med insatser inom området informations- och kommunikationsteknologi (ICT) för och i utveckling (vilket brukar förkortas ICT4D). Centrat stödjer och främjar lokala aktörer och gräsrotsorganisationer främst i Bolivia, Kambodja, Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda och Rwanda men också i Bangladesh, Burkina Faso, Etiopien, Mali, Moçambique och Zambia. Detta genom att bidra med stöd till relevanta ICT-lösningar samt med att skapa och stödja nätverk för samarbeten. Tillsammans med partners inom akademin, civila samhället, regering och privata sektorn främjar Spider utvecklingen av infrastruktur, metoder och kapacitet inom tre tematiska områden: 1) transparens och ansvarsutkrävande, 2) utbildning, och 3) hälsa. Detta med mänskliga rättigheter som utgångspunkt.

description.narrative: Key achievements in 2018 include: -The education program had 8 projects that enabled 16,204 students to access quality education. It also supported vocational training of 1,508 women and men, pedagogic training of 754 teachers and training of researchers and 280 librarians on open access policy. -The health and wellbeing program supported 12 digital health projects that tackled communicable and non-communicable diseases, maternal and child health and strengthening of health care systems. The supported projects ensured inclusion by directly addressing the health needs of marginalized groups such as the sexual minority, disabled and young people. -The transparency and accountability program supported 8 projects done through supporting organizations that collect, aggregate, disseminate and use open data in digital and machine readable formats. The supported projects have made information freely available to the public. The program also supported the training of journalists on aspects of accountability reporting. -The research program supported bilateral sub-programs and 19 implementation projects through planning and delivering baselines, real-time result follow-up and conducting evaluations and impact assessments. All researched ensured marginalized voices were heard and included in the interventions. Spider also managed four networks. Key achievements in 2019-2020 include: -The transparency and accountability program supported 7 projects in 2019 where the results are summarized per outcome area i)organizations make information available and actors have access to information, ii)forums and networks strengthen and channel information, and iii)available data leads to informed decision, action, or requests for more data. -The education program supported 8 projects in 2019 where results contributed in areas focused on i)students and learners have access to ICT-based education and digital content, ii)forums and networks (members) exchange ideas and experiences to using ICT for learning, and iii)institutions of learning and organizations have strengthened capacity building of teachers and increased development and accessibility of digital content. -The health and wellbeing program supported 12 projects in 2019 which contributed to results in the following areas i)citizens have access to information and health services, ii)forums and Networks strengthen capacity building of health care professionals, knowledge transfer and cost-effective public health initiatives, and iii)formal and informal health care workers/CSOs use and are aided by ICT in their provision of services and enrich data on public health. -The research program in 2019 supported the implementation of all Spider projects and contributed to building capacity and providing employment, with the objective to ensure that marginalized voices were heard and included in the interventions. 21 researchers, 16 assistants from 18 institutions in 11 countries and 3 continents received support. Spider also managed its networks as a channel for postgraduate students in ICT4D to make connections with peers and senior researchers/mentors in their field of interest. In 2019, Spider coordinated 7 bilateral university programmes of large research support between Sida and the respective institutions in Africa, South East-Asia and South America. -Update 2020 In 2020, due to the COVID-19 outbreak globally, the epidemiological spread and resulting lockdown in many partner countries, Spider has had to delay the start of its projects. Instead of starting in March which was the plan, Spider expects to kick off activities in May at the earliest. They also look at reducing the number of projects - moreover they have submitted to Sida two projects that directly respond to the pandemic which will be considered. Results achieving impact How does Spider themselves explain how they measure results? Spider uses the RBM matrix to follow up the proposed intervention’s outputs, outcomes and targets. They also use results follow-up (research) to monitor progress throughout the projects implementation including informing any modifications that may be required to achieve stipulated results. Spider also uses results to track and document any unexpected results that projects contribute to. For instance, Spider shared examples of conditions that have improved or organizations that have changed their behavior, including following: -In Health, the telehealth project for cervical cancer led to the development and accreditation of continuing professional development module on cervical cancer screening and care. The module is hosted on the Ministry of Health’s website and health workers can take at their own pace and get credits on completion. -In Transparency and Accountability, results follow-up on data portal project showed that majority of users of the portals used mobile phones. This showcased the spread of mobile phones across Cambodia. The feedback to the project was to redevelop the portal to a mobile friendly service to respond to information demand from the citizens. -In Education, the Rwandan vocational training project resulted in some of the participants proceeded to further education to gain additional qualification to improve their employability chances. Others also left pig farming project to seek employment with ICT skills gained. One participant for example went to pursue veterinary training, which will eventually put them in a better economic and social standing. Sida is in close dialogue with Spider when it comes to results reporting. Sida finds it difficult sometimes to elicit and understand the actual development impact, what is the result of the work, from reviewing what is reported. It is an area where Sida sees important need for improvement going forward.
